Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: The Williams College SMALL REU program
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the Williams College SMALL REU program, for ten weeks each summer (nine in residence at Williams and one at home), 20 to 30 undergraduates work on research projects under the direction of a faculty member. There are usually between 4 and 6 groups each summer of various sizes. Topics will be drawn from algebraic geometry, Bayesian statistics, combinatorics, commutative algebra, computational cartography, computational geometry, CR structures, discrete geometry, dynamics and ergodic theory, graph theory, hyperbolic manifolds, knot theory, mathematical biology, mathematical physics, measure theory, minimal surfaces, neural networks, number theory, parallel processing, particle collisions, probability, random matrix theory, Riemannian geometry, symmetry groups, and the topology of robotics.

The goal of this REU is to introduce undergraduates to the excitement and challenge of doing original research in mathematics. In the process, students naturally learn a great deal of background and are encouraged to present as well as publish their work, all invaluable for graduate school. The variety of mathematical activities provides a rich intellectual environment. Our nation needs a wider appreciation and understanding of mathematics, and cannot afford to leave anyone out. We have increased the numbers of women and under-represented minorities participating in the program over the last five years, and we are continuing to look for new and better ways to encourage applications from women, minorities, first generation college students, and other under-represented groups. Students, faculty and the broader mathematics community will benefit from the presentation and publication of original research. Students will develop a lifetime network of peers and mentors, and many of them will pursue graduate studies, partially because of their REU experience. Almost all students publish papers in research journals and many present their results at national and international research conferences.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant funded the activities of the Williams SMALL Rsearch Experience for Undergraduates (REU) from June 2014 to June 2017, with a no-cost extension to 2018. In that time approximately 100 students attended our program, working on original research in many areas, including Arithmetic Combinatorics, Combinatorial Geometry, Commutative Algebra,Ergodic Theory, Geometry, Harmonic Analysis, Knot Theory, MathematicalBiology, Mathematical Physics, Number Theory, and Tropical Geometry. This led to over 40 papers published in research journals (all available on the arXiv), and numerous conference presentations, ranging from AMS Sectional and National Meetings to invited talks at international conferences. Also, three of our students organized and ran the Northeast REU Conference in 2016.

In addition to the original research conducted, participants gained many skills which will serve them in whatever career they choose. These range from how to read technical papers, how to do original research, and how to write-up and present material. Many students have elected to pursue careers in mathematica or allied fields. They are joining colleagues from previous years of the program at top institutions, and also earning numerous scholarships (including Goldwaters, Churchills, and NSF graduate fellowships) in part due to their work in our program.

We have also mentored many junior colleagues (graduate students and postdocs). They have assisted us with our program, and are now prepared to run their own groups at other institutions in the future.

We have also been active in increasing participation from groups traditionally under-represented in mathematics. This includes both students in our program as well as mentoring done through a supplement to this grant. Those funds, administered by our program, were used to help our faculty and faculty and faculty from other REUs go to conferences such as SACNAS and the Math Alliance's Field of Dreams. There we talked to students about summer research, assembled lists of students interested, and encouraged them to reach out to us for help with their applications (which many took us up on).
